required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Novii External Fetal Monitoring Device: A Prospective, Randomized Comparison

brief_summary.textblock: This study will be conducted on women in labor. Fetal heart rate monitoring will be conducting using the Novii Fetal ECG/EMG system and comparing it to current standard of care external fetal heart rate and tocometry. These approaches will be compared with the respect to need for additional monitoring, amount of nursing intervention, cost and satisfaction of patients and healthcare providers.

detailed_description.textblock:
Interpretation of fetal heart rate monitoring during labor is one of the most common procedures performed in the practice of obstetrics. Continuous monitoring of the fetal heart rate is used to identify infants at risk for hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy and allow for intervention to prevent this terrible complication. The quality of the fetal heart rate signal is critical for appropriate interpretation of the characteristics that identify risk.
This is a prospective, randomized pragmatic trial comparing the Novii Fetal ECG/EMG system to external fetal heart rate and tocometry (standard of care) for the amount of time of interpretable fetal heart rate during labor. Randomization will occur in blocks based on BMI to control for the potential effect of BMI.
Fetal heart rate tracings from both groups of women will be reviewed in a blinded fashion by experienced Maternal Fetal Medicine (MFM) physicians who will assess the tracing for quality and interpretability. In addition, both approaches will be compared with respect to the need for additional monitoring modalities, amount of nursing intervention, cost and satisfaction of the patients and healthcare providers.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Women will be randomized to either standard monitoring with external Doppler and tocodynamometer or monitoring with the Novii Fetal ECG/EMG system using a computer generated randomization scheme through REDCap. Randomization will occur in blocks based on the subject's BMI. Women with a BMI < 30 will be randomized separate from women with a BMI > 30.

primary_outcome.measure: Amount of time in minutes with the interpretable fetal heart rate tracing during the course of labor.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
primary_outcome.description: Quality of the fetal heart rate for each minute of tracing will be assessed visually by 2 or more blinded reviewers. For the purpose of this study, uninterpretable fetal heart rate will be defined as continuous fetal heart rate data with one or more of the following: Data is missing for more than 75% of the minute of tracing Artifact is present for more than 25% of the minute of tracing Missing data or artifact prevents determination of baseline rate > 15 seconds of continuous missing tracing Missing data is not continuous but is sufficiently frequent that the one minute segment of tracing could not be used to determine baseline rate The total number of interpretable minutes of fetal heart tracing and the percentage of time with interpretable fetal heart tracing over the course of labor (Number of minutes with interpretable FHR/Total number of minutes in labor) will be calculated for each patient.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality and interpretability of the FHT in ten minute segments
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: a. Each 10 minute segment will be deemed to be interpretable if it meets all of the following criteria: i. Sufficient data are available to determine a baseline ii. Sufficient data are available to determine the variability of the tracing iii. Sufficient data are available to identify periodic changes in the tracing (e.g. accelerations, decelerations, etc) b. For each 10 minute segment that is called Uninterpretable, the reviewer will indicate the reason for this designation by selecting one of the following options: i. Poor signal quality due to missing data ii. Poor signal quality due to artifact iii. Adequate signal quality but intrinsic fetal heart rate makes interpretation impossible (e.g. marked variability, etc.)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number and quality of uterine contractions in each 10 minute segment:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: The number of uterine contractions per segment will be recorded b. Signal quality (amount of missing data or artifact) will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number and quality of uterine contractions in each 10 minute segment:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Signal quality (amount of missing data or artifact) will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of times fetal heart rate monitor requires adjusting:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by recording the number of times the nurse must adjust the monitoring system to obtain interpretable tracing

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of times fetal heart rate monitor requires adjusting:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of times that hand holding of the monitor is required

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Need for additional monitoring devices will be determined by the clinical care team including attending physician and/or nurses based on clinical judgment

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode will be recorded by clinical care team:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Reason 1: Poor signal quality - missing data Reason 2: Poor signal - artifact Reason 3: Need additional information (e.g. intrauterine pressure, etc.) Reason 4: Patient preference Reason 5: Provider preference

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode will be recorded by clinical care team:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Reason 2: Poor signal - artifact Reason 3: Need additional information (e.g. intrauterine pressure, etc.) Reason 4: Patient preference Reason 5: Provider preference

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode will be recorded by clinical care team:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Reason 3: Need additional information (e.g. intrauterine pressure, etc.) Reason 4: Patient preference Reason 5: Provider preference

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode will be recorded by clinical care team:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Reason 4: Patient preference Reason 5: Provider preference

secondary_outcome.measure: Need for additional monitoring devices such as change from Novii to standard monitoring devices or the use of intrauterine pressure catheter or fetal scalp electrode will be recorded by clinical care team:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Reason 5: Provider preference

secondary_outcome.measure: Nursing time required for care:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: We will record the amount of time that the nurses spend at the bedside to adjust the monitor b. Nurses will record the time and reasons that they enter the room

secondary_outcome.measure: Nursing time required for care:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time of randomization until time of delivery (up to 48 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Nurses will record the time and reasons that they enter the room

secondary_outcome.measure: Overall cost of care:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Total charge for care from admission to Labor and Delivery to transfer to postpartum care will be recorded for all patients

secondary_outcome.measure: Overall cost of care:
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Delivery type and indication

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Length of labor
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Length of labor recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Delivery type
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Type of delivery recorded (e.g., vaginal, cesarean section, etc.)

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Indication for forceps/vacuum extraction or cesarean section, if performed
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Clinical indication for forceps/vacuum extraction or cesarean section delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Estimated blood loss
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Amount of blood loss (cc) recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Presence and severity of perineal lacerations
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Lacerations and degree of laceration recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Intra-amniotic infection (clinical chorioamnionitis or triple I)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Infections documented

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal outcomes - Presence of clinical endometritis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization for labor, delivery, and recovery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Endometritis diagnosis recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal outcomes - APGAR Scores
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization after delivery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: APGAR scores recorded at 1 minute, 5 minutes, and 10 minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal outcomes - Need for ICU Admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization after delivery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Recorded NICU admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal outcomes - Birthweight
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization after delivery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Infant birthweight (grams)

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal outcomes - Neonatal Sex
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospitalization after delivery - 2-4 days
secondary_outcome.description: Neonatal sex recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient and provider satisfaction - Patient Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 7 days after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction survey completed by patient after delivery of infant

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient and provider satisfaction - Nurse Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 7 days after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction survey completed by nurse attending labor/delivery after delivery of infant

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient and provider satisfaction - Attending Physician/Midwife Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 7 days after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction survey completed by physician/midwife attending labor/delivery after delivery of infant

arm_group.description: These patients will have the Novii ECG/EMG system placed throughout labor and delivery, unless a provider or investigator determines that a different device (internal or external) is necessary for a better signal.
A standard external monitor will be placed throughout labor and delivery, unless a provider or investigator determines that an internal device is necessary for a better signal.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women ≥ 18 years of age; gestational age ≥ 37 weeks
- Singleton pregnancy.
- These women will be those presenting to Labor and Delivery for one of the following:
- Rule out labor
- Spontaneous labor
- Induction of labor
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age < 18 years old; multiple gestation pregnancy; gestational age < 37 weeks
- Fetal distress or vaginal bleeding prior to monitor placement
- Previous cesarean section
- Planned cesarean delivery.
- Women who are enrolled in the study but have less than 1 hour of fetal heart rate monitoring after randomization will be excluded from analysis.

Accuracy and reliability of fetal heart rate monitoring using maternal abdominal surface electrodes. Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 2012 Nov;91(11):1306-13. doi: 10.1111/j.1600-0412.2012.01533.x. Epub 2012 Oct 19.

Cohen WR, Hayes-Gill B. Influence of maternal body mass index on accuracy and reliability of external fetal monitoring techniques. Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 2014 Jun;93(6):590-5. doi: 10.1111/aogs.12387. Epub 2014 Apr 30.
Dawes GS, Visser GH, Goodman JD, Redman CW. Numerical analysis of the human fetal heart rate: the quality of ultrasound records. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 1981 Sep 1;141(1):43-52.
Rooth G, Huch A, Huch R (1987) FIGO news: guidelines for the use of fetal monitoring. Int J Gynaecol Obstet 25:159-167

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor, Division of Maternal Fetal Medicine
